TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: -1.8pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">American Airlines, Inc. (American, Company), principal subsidiary AMR Corporation (AMR), founded 1934.&#160;&#160;All American&#8217;s common stock owned AMR.&#160;&#160;At end 2009, American provided scheduled jet service approximately 160 destinations North America, Caribbean, Latin America, Europe Asia.</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: -1.8pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">In addition, American capacity purchase agreements wholly-owned subsidiaries AMR, American Eagle Airlines, Inc. Executive Airlines, Inc. (collectively, AMR Eagle AMR Eagle carriers), an&#160;&#160;independently owned regional airline, business &#8220;AmericanConnection&#8221; (the AmericanConnection&#174; carrier). The AMR Eagle AmericanConnection&#174; carriers provide connecting service American&#8217;s high-traffic cities smaller markets United States (U.S.), Canada, Caribbean.</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">The AMR Eagle fleet operated feed passenger traffic American pursuant capacity purchase agreement American AMR Eagle American receives passenger revenue flights pays AMR Eagle fee flight.&#160;&#160;The capacity purchase agreement reflects Company believes current market rates received regional carriers similar flying.&#160;&#160;Amounts paid AMR Eagle capacity purchase agreement pay operating expenses AMR Eagle, crew expenses, maintenance aircraft ownership.&#160;&#160;As December 31, 2009, AMR Eagle operated 1,500 daily departures, offering scheduled passenger service 150 destinations North America, Caribbean.&#160;&#160;On separate company basis, AMR Eagle reported $2.1 billion revenue 2009.&#160;&#160;However, historical financial information indicative AMR Eagle&#8217;s future revenues AMR Eagle stand-alone entity.&#160;&#160;</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: -1.8pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">American, AMR Eagle, AmericanConnection&#174; airline serve 250 cities 40 countries with, average, 3,400 daily flights. The combined network fleet numbers approximately 900 aircraft. American Airlines founding member <font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold">one</font>world&#174; Alliance, enables member airlines offer customers services benefits member airline provide individually. These services include broader route network, opportunities earn redeem frequent flyer miles combined <font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold">one</font>world network airport lounges.&#160;&#160;Together, <font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold">one</font>world members serve 700 destinations approximately 150 countries, 8,000 daily departures.&#160;&#160;American largest scheduled air freight carriers world, providing wide range freight mail services shippers system onboard American&#8217;s passenger fleet.</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; FONT-WEIGHT: bold">Security</font>&#160;&#160;&#160;In November 2001, Aviation Transportation Security Act (ATSA) enacted U.S.&#160;&#160;The ATSA created government agency, Transportation Security Administration (TSA), part Department Homeland Security responsible aviation security.&#160;&#160;The ATSA mandates TSA provide screening passengers property, including U.S. mail, cargo, carry-on checked baggage, articles carried aboard passenger aircraft. The ATSA security flight decks aircraft requires federal air marshals present flights.</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: -1.8pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Effective February 1, 2002, ATSA imposed $2.50 enplanement security service fee, collected air carriers submitted government pay enhanced security measures. Additionally, air carriers annually required submit government amount equal air carriers paid screening passengers property 2000.&#160;&#160;In recent years, government sought increase fees spending proposals Department Homeland Security. American carriers announced opposition proposals assurance increase fees passed customers.</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: -1.8pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold">Airline Fares</font>&#160;&#160;&#160;Airlines permitted establish domestic fares governmental regulation. maintains authority international fares, rates charges, applies authority limited basis.&#160;&#160;In addition, international fares rates subject jurisdiction governments foreign countries Company serves.&#160;&#160;While air carriers required file adhere international fare rate tariffs, substantial commissions, fare overrides discounts travel agents, brokers wholesalers characterize international markets.</font> <br> <div id="PGBRK" style="MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt"> <div id="FTR">&#160;</div> <div id="PN" style="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER: always"> <div style="WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-ALIGN: center"> <hr style="COLOR: black" noshade size="2"></div></div> <div id="HDR">&#160;</div></div></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold">Airport Access&#160; &#160;</font>Historically, FAA designated John F. Kennedy International (JFK) Airport, La Guardia (LGA) Airport Washington Reagan airports high-density traffic airports.&#160; The high-density rule limited number Instrument Flight Rule operations - take-offs landings - permitted hour required &#8220;take-off/landing slot right&#8221; support operation.&#160; The high density rule repealed JFK LGA; however, airports remain subject operating restrictions.</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; FONT-WEIGHT: bold">Environmental Matters</font>&#160;&#160;&#160;The Company subject laws government regulations environmental matters employee safety health U.S. countries.&#160;&#160;U.S. federal laws impact Company include Airport Noise Capacity Act 1990 (ANCA), Clean Air Act, Resource Conservation Recovery Act, Clean Water Act, Safe Drinking Water Act, Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation Liability Act (CERCLA Superfund Act).&#160;&#160;Certain operations Company subject oversight Occupational Safety Health Administration (OSHA) employee safety health matters.&#160;&#160;The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), OSHA, federal agencies authorized promulgate regulations impact Company's operations.&#160;&#160;In addition federal activities, states delegated authorities aforementioned federal statutes.&#160;&#160;Many state local governments adopted environmental employee safety health laws regulations, similar stricter federal requirements.</font></div> <div id="PN" style="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER: always"> <div style="WIDTH: 100%; period commences.&#160;&#160;During period (or after), Presidential Emergency Board (PEB) established, examines parties&#8217; positions recommends solution.&#160;&#160;The PEB process lasts 30 days &#8220;cooling off&#8221; period 30 days.&#160;&#160;At end &#8220;cooling off&#8221; period, agreement reached action Congress, labor organization exercise &#8220;self-help,&#8221; strike, airline resort &#8220;self-help,&#8221; WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt"> <div id="FTR">&#160;</div> <div id="PN" style="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER: always"> <div style="WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-ALIGN: center"> <hr style="COLOR: black" noshade size="2"></div></div> <div id="HDR">&#160;</div></div><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">ITEM 3.&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;LEGAL PROCEEDINGS</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: -1.8pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Between April 3, 2003 June 5, 2003, lawsuits filed travel agents, opted prior class action (now dismissed) pursue claims individually American, airline defendants, case, airline defendants Orbitz LLC.&#160; The cases, <font style="DISPLAY: inline; TEXT-DECORATION: underline">Tam Travel et. al., v. Delta Air Lines et. al</font>., United States District Court Northern District California, San Francisco (51 individual agencies), <font style="DISPLAY: inline; TEXT-DECORATION: underline">Paula Fausky d/b/a Timeless Travel v. American Airlines, et. al, </font>in United States District Court Northern District Ohio, Eastern Division (29 agencies) <font style="DISPLAY: inline; TEXT-DECORATION: underline">Swope Travel al. v. Orbitz et. al</font>. United States District Court Eastern District Texas, Beaumont Division (71 agencies) consolidated pre-trial purposes United States District Court Northern District Ohio, Eastern Division.&#160; Collectively, lawsuits seek damages injunctive relief alleging airline defendants Orbitz LLC: (i) conspired prevent travel agents acting effective competitors distribution airline tickets passengers violation Section 1 Sherman Act;&#160; (ii) conspired monopolize distribution common carrier air travel airports United States violation Section 2 Sherman Act; (iii) 1995 present, airline defendants conspired reduce commissions paid U.S.-based travel agents violation Section 1 Sherman Act.&#160; On September 23, 2005, <font style="DISPLAY: inline; TEXT-DECORATION: underline">Fausky</font> plaintiffs dismissed claims prejudice. &#160;On September 14, 2006, court dismissed prejudice 28 <font style="DISPLAY: inline; TEXT-DECORATION: underline">Swope</font> plaintiffs.&#160;&#160;On October 29, 2007, court dismissed actions.&#160;&#160;The <font style="DISPLAY: inline; TEXT-DECORATION: underline">Tam</font> plaintiffs appealed court&#8217;s decision, October 2, 2009, Sixth Circuit Court Appeals affirmed lower court decision.&#160;&#160;The <font style="DISPLAY: inline; TEXT-DECORATION: underline">Swope</font> plaintiffs moved case remanded Eastern District Texas. &#160;American continues vigorously defend lawsuits.&#160; A final adverse court decision awarding substantial money damages placing material restrictions Company&#8217;s distribution practices material adverse impact Company.</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">On July 12, 2004, consolidated class action complaint subsequently amended November 30, 2004, filed American Association Professional Flight Attendants (APFA), union represents American&#8217;s flight attendants (<font style="DISPLAY: inline; TEXT-DECORATION: underline">Ann M. Marcoux, al., v. American Airlines Inc., al.</font> United States District Court Eastern District New York). While class certified, lawsuit seeks behalf American&#8217;s flight attendants subclasses set obtain damages allegedly resulting April 2003 Collective Bargaining Agreement referred Restructuring Participation Agreement (RPA). The RPA labor agreements American successfully reached unions order avoid filing bankruptcy 2003.&#160;&#160;In related case <font style="DISPLAY: inline; TEXT-DECORATION: underline">(Sherry Cooper, al. v. TWA Airlines, LLC, al.</font>, United States District Court Eastern District New York), court denied preliminary injunction implementation RPA September 30, 2003. The <font style="DISPLAY: inline; TEXT-DECORATION: underline">Marcoux</font> suit alleges claims APFA American relating RPA ratification vote RPA individual APFA members, including: violation Labor Management Reporting Disclosure Act (LMRDA) APFA&#8217;s Constitution By-laws, violation APFA duty fair representation members, violation American provisions Railway Labor Act (RLA) improper coercion flight attendants voting changing vote ratification, violations Racketeer Influenced Corrupt Organizations&#160;Act 1970 (RICO). On March 28, 2006, district court dismissed state law claims American, LMRDA claims APFA, claimed violations RICO.&#160;&#160;On July 22, 2008, district court granted summary judgment American APFA remaining claimed violations RLA duty fair representation American APFA (as LMRDA claim claim APFA breach constitution).&#160;&#160;A notice appeal filed behalf purported class flight attendants. On September 21, 2009, U.S. Court Appeals Second Circuit affirmed district court&#8217;s decision favor American APFA.&#160;&#160;The plaintiffs seeking review U.S. Supreme Court decision Court Appeals.&#160;&#160;Although Company believes case merit American APFA vigorously defended lawsuit, final adverse court decision invalidating RPA awarding substantial money damages material adverse impact Company.</font> <br> <div id="PGBRK" style="MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt"> <div id="FTR"> <div id="GLFTR" style="WIDTH: 100%" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 8pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160; </font></div></div> <div id="PN" style="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER: always"> <div style="WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-ALIGN: center"> <hr style="COLOR: black" noshade size="2"></div></div> <div id="HDR">&#160;</div></div> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">On February 14, 2006, Antitrust Division United States Department Justice (DOJ) served Company grand jury subpoena part ongoing investigation criminal violations antitrust laws domestic foreign air cargo carriers. At time, Company target DOJ investigation.&#160; The New Zealand Commerce Commission notified Company February 17, 2006 investigating Company cargo carriers entered agreements relating fuel surcharges, security surcharges, war-risk surcharges, customs clearance surcharges.&#160; On February 22, 2006, Company received letter Swiss Competition Commission informing Company investigating Company cargo carriers entered agreements relating fuel surcharges, security surcharges, war-risk surcharges, customs clearance surcharges.&#160;&#160;On March 11, 2008, Company received Swiss Competition Commission request information concerning, things, scope organization Company&#8217;s activities Switzerland.&#160;&#160;On December 19, 2006 June 12, 2007, Company received requests information European Commission seeking information Company's corporate structure, revenue pricing announcements air cargo shipments European Union.&#160;&#160;On January 23, 2007, Brazilian competition authorities, part ongoing investigation, conducted unannounced search Company&#8217;s cargo facilities Sao Paulo, Brazil.&#160; On April 24, 2008, Brazilian competition authorities charged Company violating Brazilian competition laws.&#160; On December 31, 2009, Brazilian competition authorities made non-binding recommendation Brazilian competition tribunal find Company violation competition laws.&#160; The authorities investigating Company foreign domestic air carriers violated Brazilian competition laws illegally conspiring set fuel surcharges cargo shipments.&#160; The Company vigorously contesting allegations preliminary findings Brazilian competition authorities.&#160;&#160;On June 27, 2007 October 31, 2007, Company received requests information Australian Competition Consumer Commission seeking information fuel surcharges imposed Company cargo shipments Australia structure Company's cargo operations. On September 1, 2008, Company received request Korea Fair Trade Commission seeking information cargo rates surcharges structure Company&#8217;s activities Korea.<font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt">&#160;</font>On December 18, 2007, European Commission issued Statement Objection (SO) 26 airlines, including Company.&#160;&#160;The alleges carriers participated conspiracy set surcharges cargo shipments violation EU law.&#160;&#160;The states that, event allegations affirmed, Commission impose fines Company.&#160;&#160;The Company intends vigorously contest allegations findings EU laws, intends cooperate fully pending investigations. FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">The Company recorded net loss $1.5 billion 2009 compared net loss $2.5 billion 2008.&#160;&#160;The Company&#8217;s 2009 net loss primarily attributable significant decrease passenger revenue due lower traffic passenger yield.&#160;&#160;In 2009, Company experienced weak demand air travel driven continuing severe downturn global economy.&#160;&#160;In addition, result reduced demand, substantial fare discounting industry, resulted decreased passenger yield.&#160;&#160;Mainline passenger revenue decreased $3.2 billion $15.0 billion year ended December 31, 2009 compared 2008.&#160;&#160;Mainline passenger unit revenues decreased 11.1 percent 2009 due 11.2 percent decrease passenger yield compared 2008 partially offset load factor increase approximately 0.1 points.&#160;&#160;Passenger yield remains low Company&#8217;s peak yield set year 2000, cumulative inflation approximately 26 percent time frame.&#160;&#160;The Company believes result fragmented industry numerous competitors excess capacity, increased low cost carrier competition, increased price competition due internet, factors.&#160;&#160;Since deregulation 1978, Company&#8217;s passenger yield increased 64 percent, Consumer Price Index (CPI), measured U.S. Department Labor Bureau Labor Statistics, grown 220 percent.&#160;&#160;The Company believes increases passenger yield continue significantly lag CPI indefinitely.</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt"> <div id="FTR">&#160;</div> <div id="PN" style="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER: always"> <div style="WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-ALIGN: center"> <hr style="COLOR: black" noshade size="2"></div></div> <div id="HDR">&#160;</div></div></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; FONT-WEIGHT: bold; FONT-STYLE: italic">2009 Compared 2008&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;</font>The Company&#8217;s revenues decreased approximately $3.8 billion, 16.0 percent, $19.9 billion 2009 compared 2008. American&#8217;s passenger revenues decreased 17.5 percent, $3.2 billion, capacity decrease approximately 7.2 percent year year. Mainline passenger load factor increased approximately 0.1 points 80.7 percent passenger revenue yield passenger mile decreased 11.2 percent 12.28 cents.&#160;&#160;This resulted decrease passenger revenue seat mile (RASM) 11.1 percent 9.91 cents. In 2009, American derived approximately 60 percent passenger revenues domestic operations approximately 40 percent international operations (flights serving international destinations).&#160;&#160;Following additional information American&#8217;s domestic international RASM capacity:</font></div> <div align="left"> <table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="100%" style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; passenger revenues, based industry standard proration agreements flights connecting American flights, decreased $474 million, 19.1 percent, $2.0 billion result reduction capacity, decreased passenger traffic lower yield.&#160;&#160;Regional Affiliates&#8217; traffic decreased 6.7 percent 8.3 billion revenue passenger miles (RPMs), capacity decreased 8.2 percent 11.6 billion ASMs, resulting 1.2 point increase passenger load factor 71.4 percent.</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: -1.8pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Other revenues increased 8.0 percent, $169 million, $2.3 billion due increases passenger service charges instituted year 2008.</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">The Board Directors Stockholder</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">American Airlines, Inc.</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; Our responsibility express opinion financial statements schedule based audits.</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160;</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">We conducted audits accordance standards Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States). Those standards require plan perform audit obtain reasonable assurance financial statements free material misstatement. An audit includes examining, test basis, evidence supporting amounts disclosures financial statements. An audit includes assessing accounting principles significant estimates made management, evaluating financial statement presentation. We audits provide reasonable basis opinion.</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160;</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">In opinion, financial statements referred present fairly, material respects, consolidated financial position American Airlines, Inc. December 31, 2009 2008 consolidated results operations cash flows years period ended December 31, 2009, conformity U.S. generally accepted accounting principles.&#160;&#160;Also, opinion, related financial statement schedule, considered relation basic financial statements whole, presents fairly, material respects, information set therein.</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">We audited, accordance standards Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), American Airlines, Inc.&#8217;s internal control financial reporting December 31, 2009, based criteria established Internal Control&#8212;Integrated Framework issued Committee Sponsoring Organizations Treadway Commission report dated February 17, 2010 expressed unqualified opinion thereon.</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160;</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 270pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">The Company general indemnity clauses airport real estate leases Company lessee indemnifies lessor (and related parties) liabilities related Company&#8217;s leased property.&#160;&#160;Generally, indemnifications cover liabilities resulting negligence indemnified parties, liabilities resulting gross negligence willful misconduct indemnified parties.&#160;&#160;In addition, Company environmental indemnities leases contamination related Company&#8217;s leased property.</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Under contracts parties, Company indemnifies party legal liability arising action party, parties. The terms contracts vary potential exposure indemnities determined. Generally, Company liability insurance protecting Company obligations undertaken indemnities.</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">The Company involved claims litigation related operations. TEXT-DECORATION: underline">7.&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; TEXT-DECORATION: underline">Financial Instruments Risk Management</font></font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold">Fuel Price Risk Management&#160;&#160;&#160;</font>As part Company's risk management program, variety financial instruments, primarily heating oil option collar contracts, cash flow hedges mitigate commodity price risk.&#160;&#160;The Company hold issue derivative financial instruments trading purposes.&#160;&#160;As December 31, 2009, Company fuel derivative contracts outstanding covering 20 million barrels jet fuel settled 24 months.&#160;&#160;A deterioration Company&#8217;s liquidity position negatively affect Company&#8217;s ability hedge fuel future.</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">In accordance U.S. GAAP, Company assesses, inception hedge ongoing basis, derivatives hedging transactions highly effective offsetting cash flows hedged items.&#160;&#160;Derivatives meet requirements granted special hedge accounting treatment, Company&#8217;s hedges generally meet requirements.&#160;&#160;Accordingly, Company&#8217;s fuel derivative contracts accounted cash flow hedges, fair Company&#8217;s hedging contracts recorded Current Assets Current Liabilities accompanying consolidated balance sheets underlying jet fuel purchased. The Company determines ineffective portion fuel hedge contracts comparing cumulative change total fuel hedge contract, group fuel hedge contracts, cumulative change hypothetical jet fuel hedge.&#160;&#160;If total cumulative change fuel hedge contract offsets total cumulative change hypothetical jet fuel hedge, difference considered ineffective immediately recognized component Aircraft fuel expense.&#160;&#160;Effective gains losses fuel hedging contracts deferred Accumulated comprehensive income (loss) recognized earnings component Aircraft fuel expense underlying jet fuel hedged used.</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Ineffectiveness inherent hedging jet fuel derivative positions based crude oil crude oil related commodities.&#160;&#160;In assessing effectiveness, Company regression model determine correlation change prices commodities hedge jet fuel (e.g., NYMEX Heating oil) change price jet fuel.&#160;&#160;The Company monitors actual dollar offset hedges&#8217; market values compared hypothetical jet fuel hedges.&#160;&#160;The fuel hedge contracts generally deemed &#8220;highly effective&#8221; R-squared greater 80 percent dollar offset correlation 80 percent 125 percent.&#160;&#160;The Company discontinues hedge accounting prospectively determines derivative longer expected highly effective hedge decides discontinue hedging relationship.&#160;&#160;Subsequently, fair derivatives marked market earnings period change.</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">For years ended December 31, 2009, 2008 2007, Company recognized net gains (losses) approximately ($591) million, $344 million $215 million, respectively, component Aircraft fuel expense accompanying consolidated statements operations related fuel hedging agreements, including ineffective portion hedges.&#160;&#160;The fair Company&#8217;s fuel hedging agreements December 31, 2009 2008, representing amount Company receive (pay) termination agreements, totaled $57 million ($450) million, respectively, excludes payable years related contracts settled December year.&#160;&#160;As December 31, 2009, Company estimates twelve months reclassify Accumulated comprehensive loss earnings approximately $66 million $8 million net losses (based prices December 31, 2009) related fuel derivative hedges American AMR Eagle, respectively, including losses terminated contracts bankrupt counterparty 2008.</font> <br> <div id="PGBRK" style="MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; </font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; TEXT-DECORATION: underline">Financial Instruments Risk Management (Continued)</font></font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Under special tax rules (the Section 382 Limitation), cumulative stock ownership material shareholders exceeding 50 percent 3-year period potentially limit company&#8217;s future net operating losses tax credits (NOL&#8217;s). &#160;The Section 382 Limitation increased by&#160;certain &#8220;built-in gains,&#8221; provided current IRS guidance<font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold">. &#160;</font>Based information, Company believes subject Section 382 Limitation.&#160; If triggered current conditions, Section 382 Limitation expected significantly impact recorded deferred taxes timing utilization of&#160;the Company&#8217;s NOL's.</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; American Airlines, Inc.&#8217;s management responsible maintaining effective internal control financial reporting assessment effectiveness internal control financial reporting included accompanying &#8220;Management&#8217;s Report Internal Control Financial Reporting.&#8221; Our responsibility express opinion company&#8217;s internal control financial reporting based audit.</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">We conducted audit accordance standards Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States). Those standards require plan perform audit obtain reasonable assurance effective internal control financial reporting maintained material respects. Our audit included obtaining understanding internal control financial reporting, assessing risk material weakness exists, testing evaluating design operating effectiveness internal control based assessed risk, performing procedures considered circumstances. We audit reasonable basis opinion.</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">A company&#8217;s internal control financial reporting process designed provide reasonable assurance reliability financial reporting preparation financial statements external purposes accordance generally accepted accounting principles. A company&#8217;s internal control financial reporting includes policies procedures (1) pertain maintenance records that, reasonable detail, accurately fairly reflect transactions dispositions assets company; (2) provide reasonable assurance transactions recorded permit preparation financial statements accordance generally accepted accounting principles, receipts expenditures company made accordance authorizations management directors company; (3) provide reasonable assurance prevention timely detection unauthorized acquisition, use, disposition company&#8217;s assets material effect financial statements.</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Because inherent limitations, internal control financial reporting prevent detect misstatements.&#160;&#160;Also, projections evaluation effectiveness future periods subject risk controls inadequate conditions, degree compliance policies procedures deteriorate.</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">In opinion, American Airlines, Inc. maintained, material respects, effective internal control financial reporting December 31, 2009, based COSO criteria.</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">We audited, accordance standards Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), consolidated balance sheets American Airlines, Inc. December 31, 2009 2008, related consolidated statements operations, stockholder&#8217;s equity (deficit) cash flows years period ended December 31, 2009 American Airlines, Inc. report dated February 17, 2010 expressed unqualified opinion thereon.</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 216pt; TEXT-INDENT: 36pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold">Audit-Related Fees:&#160;&#160;</font>Consists fees billed assurance related services related performance audit review Company&#8217;s consolidated financial statements reported &#8220;Audit Fees&#8221;.&#160;&#160;These services include employee benefit plan audits, accounting consultations auditing work proposed transactions, attest services required statute regulation, consultations financial accounting reporting standards.</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 18pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold">Tax Fees:&#160;&#160;</font>Consists tax compliance/preparation tax services. Tax compliance/preparation consists fees billed professional services related federal, state international tax compliance, assistance tax audits appeals, expatriate tax services, assistance related impact mergers, acquisitions divestitures tax return preparation.&#160;&#160;Other tax services consist fees billed miscellaneous tax consulting planning.</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br> <div id="PGBRK" style="MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt"> <div id="FTR">&#160;</div> <div id="PN" style="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER: always"> <div style="WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-ALIGN: center"> <hr style="COLOR: black" noshade size="2"></div></div> <div id="HDR">&#160;</div></div><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Audit Pre-Approval Audit Permissible Non-Audit Services Independent Auditors</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">The AMR Audit Committee pre-approves audit permissible non-audit services provided Ernst &amp; Young.&#160;&#160;These services include audit services, audit-related services, tax services services. The Audit Committee adopted policy pre-approval services provided Ernst &amp; Young. Under policy, pre-approval generally provided year pre-approval detailed service category services includes anticipated budget.&#160;&#160;In addition, Committee pre-approve services case-by-case basis. The Audit Committee delegated pre-approval authority Chair Committee. Pursuant delegation, Chair report pre-approval decision Committee meeting pre-approval obtained.</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div> <table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="100%" style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; (Customer);</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">RECITALS:</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">1.&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;Boeing Customer entered Purchase Agreement No. 1980 dated October 31, 1997, amended supplemented (capitalized terms definition meanings therefor Purchase Agreement) relating Boeing Model 777-223IGW aircraft (the Purchase Agreement).</font></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"> <br></div> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">2.&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;In Letter Agreement No. 6-1162-AKP-109R1 Purchase Agreement, things, Boeing agreed issue [CONFIDENTIAL PORTION OMITTED FILED SEPARATELY COMMISSION PURSUANT A REQUEST CONFIDENTIAL TREATMENT].&#160;&#160;Boeing Customer amend letter agreement set [CONFIDENTIAL PORTION OMITTED FILED SEPARATELY COMMISSION PURSUANT A REQUEST CONFIDENTIAL TREATMENT].</font></div> <br> <div id="PGBRK" style="MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt"> <div id="FTR"> <div style="WIDTH: 100%" align="left"> <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">P.A.
